en: "It enables prisoners to form an awareness of the gravity of their mistakes," he said.
kin: Ati: "Bituma imfungwa zimenyekanisha uburemere bw'amakosa yabo".
mt0: "It makes the prisoners realise the seriousness of their sins."

en: Graduating from the program doesn't make inmates automatically eligible for early release, but does increase their chances of getting a royal pardon or a reduced sentence. That's been the case for just over half the program's 222 graduates so far, the prison administration says. Since 2019, the training has also been offered to women convicted under Morocco's Anti-Terrorism Act. Ten women have graduated so far — all of them since released, including eight with pardons.
kin: Kurangiza porogaramu ntibituma abagororwa bahita bemererwa kurekurwa hakiri kare, ariko byongera amahirwe yo kubona imbabazi zumwami cyangwa kugabanyirizwa ibihano. Ubuyobozi bwa gereza buvuga ko ibyo byabaye ku barenga kimwe cya kabiri cy'abanyeshuri 222 barangije porogaramu kugeza ubu. Kuva mu mwaka wa 2019, amahugurwa yahawe kandi abagore bahamwe n'icyaha hakurikijwe itegeko ryo kurwanya iterabwoba muri Maroc. Abagore icumi barangije kugeza ubu - bose kuva barekuwe, harimo umunani bafite imbabazi.

mt0: This program is called "Moussala," meaning "reconciliation" in Arabic, and is given to prisoners who have shown willingness to reject violence.

en: A member of Iran's syndicate of car parts manufacturers says Iranian producers have an opportunity to export their wares to a Russian carmaker, state media reported.

en: The late Monday report quoted Hossein Bahrainian as saying "a prominent Russian car maker" requested parts from Iran. He did not name the manufacturer. He said it requested brake parts, airbags, air-conditioner parts and other components.
kin: Raporo yo ku wa mbere yarangiye ivuga ko Hossein Bahrein yavuze ko "uruganda rukomeye rw’imodoka yo mu Burusiya" rwasabye ibice muri Irani. Ntiyavuze uwabikoze. Yavuze ko isaba ibice bya feri, ibikapu byo mu kirere, ibyuma bifata ibyuma bikonjesha n'ibindi bikoresho.
mt0: The report ended with Hossein Bahrein saying that "a major Russian car factory" had asked for parts in Iran. He didn't say who did it. He said it asked for pieces of ferris, airbags, hydraulic cables and other equipment.

en: Both Iran and Russia are under U.S. sanctions but the export of Iranian cars and car parts is not subject to sanctions.

en: Diversity, New Perspectives Are Applied to Middle East Coverage
kin: Dutandukanye, Ibitekerezo bishya bikoreshwa muburasirazuba bwo hagati

en: Natalia Sancha has always adopted a collaborative approach to journalism. When out on assignment, she speaks to others covering the same story about their perspectives.
kin: Nataliya Sancha yamye afata inzira yo gufatanya mubanyamakuru. Iyo asohotse mukoro, avugana nabandi bavuga inkuru imwe kubitekerezo byabo.
mt0: Nataliya Sancha has taken the path of cooperation with journalists. When she is out of the classroom, she speaks to others who share the same opinion.

en: This partly stems from an interest in telling underreported stories, but as a female journalist in a male-dominated region, she says collaboration and supporting the women she works with have always been important.
kin: Ibi bimwe bituruka ku gushimishwa no kuvuga inkuru zidasobanutse, ariko nkumunyamakuru wumugore mukarere kariganjemo abagabo, avuga ko ubufatanye no gutera inkunga abagore bakorana byahoze ari ngombwa.
mt0: This is sometimes a result of being acknowledged for telling unexplained stories, but as a woman journalist in a rural area where men are a majority, he says that cooperation and support for women working together was necessary.

en: "I would talk to male and female journalists, and I always realized that women had a similar perspective, because we had similar experiences while covering the story," the 42-year-old journalist said.
kin: Umunyamakuru w'imyaka 42 yagize ati: "Naganiriye n'abanyamakuru b'abagabo n'abagore, kandi buri gihe nabonaga ko abagore bafite imyumvire imwe, kuko natwe twagize ibyabaye mugihe twatangaga inkuru".
mt0: The 42-year-old journalist said: "I talked to both men and women, and I always found that women have the same attitude, because we had experiences when we started reporting stories."

en: That collaborative approach came into play in 2020 when a publisher asked Sancha if she was interested in writing a book about Syria.
kin: Ubwo buryo bwo gufatanya bwatangiye gukurikizwa mu 2020 ubwo umubwiriza yabazaga Sancha niba ashishikajwe no kwandika igitabo kivuga kuri Siriya.
mt0: If you cannot translate, just say you don't know. The partnership began in 2020 when a spokesman asked Sancha if he was interested in writing a book about Syria.

en: She countered with a better offer.
kin: Yarwanyije icyifuzo cyiza.

en: "I told him that a collective narrative by women journalists about the broader region would have a different effect," she said. "I could have written the book myself, but it would not have the same sense."
kin: Ati: "Namubwiye ko inkuru rusange y'abanyamakuru b'abagore ivuga ku karere kanini byagira ingaruka zitandukanye." "Nanjye ubwanjye nashoboraga kwandika igitabo, ariko ntabwo cyari kumva kimwe."
mt0: "I told him that a general female news report on a large area would have different effects." "I could write a book, but it didn't feel the same."

en: Originally from Andalusia in southern Spain, Sancha spent the past 14 years in the Middle East covering conflicts in Iraq, Syria and Yemen, and reporting from Egypt, Lebanon and Tunisia.
kin: Sancha ukomoka muri Andalusiya mu majyepfo ya Espagne, Sancha yamaze imyaka 14 ishize mu burasirazuba bwo hagati yerekana amakimbirane yo muri Iraki, Siriya na Yemeni, kandi atanga raporo avuye muri Egiputa, Libani na Tuniziya.
mt0: Sancha is from Andalusia in the north of Spain, Sancha has been in the Middle East for 14 years reporting on the conflicts in Iraq, Syria and Yemen, and reports from Egypt, Lebanon and Tunisia.

en: She has been working more recently with the European Union communications department, after leaving Beirut for health reasons following a mass explosion that rocked the city in 2020.
kin: Aherutse gukorana n’ishami ry’itumanaho ry’umuryango w’ubumwe bw’ibihugu by’Uburayi, nyuma yo kuva i Beirut kubera impamvu z’ubuzima nyuma y’igiturika kinini cyibasiye umujyi muri 2020.
mt0: He has recently been working with the European Union's communication department, after leaving Beirut for health reasons after a large earthquake hit the city in 2020.

en: Women "have a different experience because we would go to places that our male colleagues were not used to. Not because we're smarter, but just because the majority of the region is still Arab, Muslim and gender-segregated," Sancha told VOA.
kin: Sancha yabwiye VOA ati: "Abagore" bafite uburambe butandukanye kuko twajya ahantu bagenzi bacu b'igitsina gabo batamenyereye. Ntabwo ari ukubera ko turi abanyabwenge, ahubwo ni ukubera ko igice kinini cy'akarere kikiri abarabu, abayisilamu ndetse n'abagabo."
mt0: Sancha told VOA: "We're different because we go places our male partners don't know. It's not because we're intelligent, it's because most of the region is still Arab, Muslim, and a man."

en: Having women reporters has an impact, she noted.
kin: Yavuze ko kugira abanyamakuru b'abagore bigira ingaruka.
mt0: He said that having women journalists had a positive effect.

en: "If I put myself in the position of the reader, I would prefer to have a woman telling me the story because it is going to be about 100 percent of the population, which means you are going to have a more inclusive narrative on the conflict."
kin: "Niba nishyize mu mwanya w'abasomyi, nahitamo kugira umugore umbwira inkuru kuko igiye kuba hafi 100 ku ijana by'abaturage, bivuze ko uzaba ufite inkuru zuzuye zirimo amakimbirane."
mt0: If I were in the shoes of readers, I would choose to have a woman tell me the story because it will be about 100 percent of the population, which means you will have a lot of stories filled with arguments.

en: For her book, Sancha reached out to other women who cover the Middle East, to ensure diverse perspectives from foreign and local reporters.
kin: Ku gitabo cye, Sancha yageze ku bandi bagore bavuga iburasirazuba bwo hagati, kugira ngo babone ibitekerezo bitandukanye n'abanyamakuru bo mu mahanga ndetse n'abenegihugu.
mt0: In her book, Sancha reached out to other women who speak Middle East, to get their perspectives mixed with foreign journalists and citizens.

en: The result of the nearly two-year collaboration is Bullets for All, released in Spanish in April.
kin: Ibisubizo byubufatanye bwimyaka hafi ibiri ni Bullets kuri Bose, yasohotse mu cyesipanyoli muri Mata.

en: In the book, "we tell one story with different voices that represent all the women" from the region, Sancha said.

mt0: In this book, Sancha said: "In this book," we tell the same story with different voices representing all women."

en: Each offers a personal perspective on covering historic moments, including the collapse of autocratic governments, popular protest movements and war. It also examines the discrimination and harassment women face in the newsroom and on assignment.
kin: Buri kimwe gitanga icyerekezo cyihariye cyo kwerekana ibihe byamateka, harimo gusenyuka kwa guverinoma yigenga, imyigaragambyo yamamaye nintambara. Irasuzuma kandi ivangura n'ihohoterwa abagore bahura nabyo mu cyumba cy'amakuru no ku mukoro.

en: Understanding language and culture goes a long way toward making progress in the region, says Maya Gebeily. The Reuters bureau chief for Lebanon, Syria and Jordan is one of the contributors to the book.
kin: Maya Gebeily avuga ko gusobanukirwa ururimi n'umuco bigana inzira igana ku iterambere. Umuyobozi w'ikigo cya Reuters muri Libani, Siriya na Yorodani ni umwe mu bagize uruhare muri iki gitabo.
mt0: Maya Gebeily says that understanding languages and cultures is a way to progress. The Lebanon, Syria and Iraq Reuters chief is one of the contributors to this book.

en: "There's a lot to say and show from the perspective of women reporters who were also then influenced by the women that they met as they were doing their reporting," she said.
kin: Ati: "Hariho byinshi byo kuvuga no kwerekana nkurikije uko abanyamakuru b'abagore na bo bahise bayoborwa n'abagore bahuye igihe bakoraga raporo zabo".
mt0: "There are a lot of things to say and to show because women journalists were also being treated like women when they reported their stories."

en: Born in the U.S. to Lebanese parents, Gebeily started her journalism career in 2013 with a local news site in Beirut, Lebanon. She went on to cover the region for Agence France-Presse before joining Reuters.
kin: Gebeily yavukiye muri Amerika ku babyeyi bo muri Libani, yatangiye umwuga we w'itangazamakuru mu 2013 akoresheje urubuga rw'amakuru i Beirut, muri Libani. Yakomeje yerekeza mu karere ka Agence France-Presse mbere yo kwinjira muri Reuters.
mt0: Gebeily was born in the United States of America with Libanese parents, he began his journalistic career in 2013 using a news website in Beirut, Lebanon. He continued to work for Agence France-Presse before joining Reuters.

en: Gebeily said her American and Lebanese background helped her understand the region better, which in turn has shaped her reporting. Knowing the local language is an important part of that.
kin: Gebeily yavuze ko amateka ye y'Abanyamerika na Libani yamufashije kumva neza akarere, ari nako kagize uruhare mu gutanga raporo. Kumenya ururimi rwaho nigice cyingenzi cyibyo.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. Gebeily said that his American and Lebanon experience helped him understand the region, which helped him to report. Learning the language is a part of that.

en: "When interviewing a minister or a displaced person or an activist, the most important element is getting their trust," she said. "If you're able to speak the language and make them feel comfortable from the beginning, it changes everything. It grants you a very beautiful kind of access."
kin: Ati: "Iyo ubajije minisitiri cyangwa umuntu wimuwe cyangwa umurwanashyaka, ikintu cy'ingenzi ni ukugirira icyizere." "Niba ushoboye kuvuga ururimi no gutuma bumva bamerewe neza kuva mu ntangiriro, bihindura byose. Iraguha uburyo bwiza cyane bwo kwinjira."
mt0: "When you ask a minister or a nurse or a worker, the most important thing is to be confident." "If you can speak the language and make them feel comfortable from the beginning, it changes everything. It gives you the best chance to get into the world."

en: In addition to Iraq and Lebanon, Gebeily, 30, has also traveled to Syria to cover the war against the Islamic State (IS) militant group.
kin: Usibye Iraki na Libani, Gebeily w'imyaka 30 yanagiye muri Siriya kugira ngo akurikirane intambara yo kurwanya umutwe w'abarwanyi ba Leta ya Kisilamu (IS).
mt0: In addition to Iraq and Lebanon, Gebeily, 30, also went to Syria to follow the fight against the Islamic State (IS).

en: "Ive been very privileged to access some communities directly without having to work with a translator or a fixer, which also shapes the way that the stories come out," she said.
kin: Ati: "Ive nagize amahirwe yo kugera ku baturage mu buryo butaziguye ntiriwe nkorana n'umusemuzi cyangwa uwakosoye, ibyo bikaba binerekana uburyo inkuru zisohoka".
mt0: "Ive had the opportunity to get to the people in a way that I didn't have to work with a translator or corrector, which shows how stories are published."

en: Syrian-Kurdish journalist Khabat Abbas, who has covered the war in Syria, attests to the importance of that.
kin: Umunyamakuru wa Siriya-Kurdiya, Khabat Abbas, wanditse ku ntambara yo muri Siriya, ahamya akamaro kayo.
mt0: The Syrian-Kurdish journalist, Khabat Abbas, wrote about the war in Syria, emphasizing its importance.

en: "Its knowing the language and the culture that gives people a sense of comfort to open up to you," she told VOA from Qamishli, Syria.
kin: Yatangarije VOA avuye i Qamishli, muri Siriya ati: "Kumenya ururimi n'umuco biha abantu ihumure ryo kukwugururira."
mt0: "Learning the language and culture gives people the confidence to open up." He told VOA from Qamishli, Syria. "Learning the language and culture gives people the confidence to open up."

en: That knowledge helped when Abbas, 34, was on assignment with Sancha in March 2021. They traveled to a Kurdish-run detention camp in northeast Syria and interviewed female jihadists affiliated with IS, for a story in El Pais.
kin: Ubwo bumenyi bwafashije igihe Abbas w'imyaka 34 yari mu butumwa na Sancha muri Werurwe 2021. Baragiye mu kigo cy’imfungwa cy’Abanyakorde mu majyaruguru y’amajyaruguru ya Siriya maze babaza abajihadiste b’abagore bafitanye isano na IS, kugira ngo babone inkuru muri El Pais.
mt0: This knowledge helped when Abbas, 34, was in a mission with Sancha in March 2021. They went to a prison in the north-eastern Syrian province and asked female jihadists linked to IS to get a story in El Pais.

en: "While in Qamishli [in northeast Syria], I ran into two British journalists, very good colleagues of mine, who were disappointed after Shamima Begum and other women at the camp refused to talk to them," Sancha said, referring to a young woman who left her home in Britain aged 15 to join IS.
kin: Sancha yagize ati: "Nkiri i Qamishli [mu majyaruguru y'uburasirazuba bwa Siriya], nahungiye mu banyamakuru babiri b'Abongereza, abo dukorana cyane, batengushye nyuma yuko Shamima Begum n'abandi bagore bari mu nkambi banze kuvugana nabo." wavuye iwe mu Bwongereza afite imyaka 15 yinjira muri IS.
mt0: Sancha said: "While I was in Qamishli [in the north-east of Syria], I ran into two English journalists who were close partners, who were angry after Shamima Begum and other women in the camp refused to talk to them." He went back home to England when he was 15 years old and joined Islamic State.

en: "Their fixer was a man, so the jihadist women didnt talk to them because they are radical, and they dont talk to men. But then I was able to sit with Shamima and other women, who gave fantastic interviews from inside their tents," Sancha said.
kin: "Umukosora wabo yari umugabo, ku buryo abagore ba jihadiste batavuganye nabo kubera ko ari intagondwa, kandi ntibavugana n'abagabo. Ariko rero nashoboye kwicarana na Shamima n'abandi bagore, batanga ibiganiro bitangaje bivuye mu mahema yabo." Sancha ati.
mt0: "The commander was a man, so the women of the jihadist group didn't speak to them because they were fighters, and they didn't speak to men. But I was able to sit with Shamima and other women, giving interesting talks from their tents."

en: Abbas had a role in getting to talk to those women, she added.
kin: Yongeyeho ko Abbas yagize uruhare mu kubona abo bagore.
mt0: He also said that Abbas had helped find the women.

en: Unlike Sancha and Gebeily, Abbas grew up in the marginalized Kurdish region of Syria, where until the war began in 2011, journalism effectively didnt exist.
kin: Unlike Sancha and Gebeily, Abbas grew up in the marginalized Kurdish region of Syria, where until the war began in 2011, journalism effectively didnt exist.
mt0: Like Sancha and Gebeily, Abbas grew up in the marginalized Kurdish region of Syria, where until the war began in 2011, journalism effectively didn't exist.

en: "Ordinary people in our region were used to seeing women pick up arms and fight, but they werent used to seeing a woman hold a camera on the streets and on front lines," Abbas said. "It took a lot of sacrificing for me to convince my family and society that Im as good, if not better, as my male colleagues."
kin: Bitandukanye na Sancha na Gebeily, Abbas yakuriye mu karere ka Siriya k’abasigajwe inyuma na Siriya, kugeza igihe intambara yatangiriye mu 2011, itangazamakuru ntiryabayeho.
mt0: In contrast to Sancha and Gebley, Abbas lived in the remaining Syrian region of the remaining Syrians, until the start of the war in 2011.

en: Journalism appealed to her because the story of the Middle East has often been told by male journalists, both local and foreign.
kin: Itangazamakuru ryaramushimishije kubera ko inkuru yo mu burasirazuba bwo hagati yagiye ivugwa n'abanyamakuru b'abagabo, baba abo mu mahanga ndetse n'abanyamahanga.
mt0: The media moved him because the Middle East news continued to be covered by men, foreigners and foreigners.

en: "The narrative hasnt changed because of that, but if local and international women journalists get a real chance to tell the story of the Middle East, that narrative could change, which would affect the way others see this region," Abbas said.
kin: Abbas yagize ati: "Ibitekerezo ntabwo byahindutse kubera ibyo, ariko niba abanyamakuru b’abagore bo mu karere ndetse n’amahanga babonye amahirwe nyayo yo kuvuga amateka y’iburasirazuba bwo hagati, iyo nkuru ishobora guhinduka, ibyo bikaba byagira ingaruka ku kuntu abandi babona aka karere."
mt0: Abbas said: "Opinions have not changed, but if women journalists in the region and abroad have the chance to tell the history of the Middle East, the story can change, which will affect the way others view the region."

en: Sancha also believes women in journalism have an impact on the way issues are viewed in the region, including post-traumatic stress disorder and the effect it has on female health, and subjects such as violence and alcohol.
kin: Sancha yizera kandi ko abagore mu itangazamakuru bagira ingaruka ku buryo ibibazo bigaragara mu karere, birimo ihungabana ry’ihungabana ndetse n’ingaruka bigira ku buzima bw’umugore, ndetse n’ihohoterwa n’inzoga.
mt0: Sancha also believes that women in the media affect the way problems are reported in the region, including depression and related effects on women's health, and alcoholism.

en: "We talk about all these issues that men normally wouldnt not speak about," she said.
kin: Ati: "Turaganira kuri ibyo bibazo byose abagabo ubusanzwe batavuga."

en: Iran's Guards Commander Says Israel Creating Conditions for Own Destruction
kin: Umuyobozi w'ingabo za Irani avuga ko Isiraheli ishyiraho uburyo bwo kurimbuka
mt0: The commander of the Iranian military says Israel has established a way to cross the border.

en: Israel's actions are creating conditions for its own destruction, Irans Revolutionary Guards commander on Friday told a Jerusalem Day rally at which the countrys new domestically-made Kheibar Buster missile was displayed.
kin: Ku wa gatanu, umuyobozi w’ingabo z’abasirikare barinda impinduramatwara ya Irans, yatangaje ko ibikorwa bya Isiraheli bitera uburyo bwo kurimbuka kwayo.
mt0: In the evening of Thursday, the commander of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards announced that Israel's actions threatened its escape route.

en: State television said millions of Iranians joined rallies marking Quds Day, the Arabic name for Jerusalem, in state-organized marches across the country.
kin: Televiziyo ya Leta yavuze ko miliyoni z'Abanyayirani bitabiriye imyigaragambyo yizihizaga umunsi wa Quds, izina ry'icyarabu ryitwa Yeruzalemu, mu rugendo rwateguwe na leta mu gihugu hose.
mt0: The state television reported that millions of Iranians participated in protests marking the Quds Day, a Hebrew name for Jerusalem, during a tour of the country.

en: It showed the Israeli flag being set on fire and groups of people around the country shouting choreographed "Death to America, Death to Israel" slogans.
kin: Yerekanye ibendera rya Isiraheli ritwikwa hamwe nitsinda ryabantu hirya no hino basakuza koreografiya "Urupfu muri Amerika, Urupfu kuri Isiraheli".
mt0: He showed the Israeli flag being thrown along with a group of people across the world chanting the erotic erotic erotic "Death in America, Death in Israel".

en: Supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said in a televised speech that anti-Israeli protests and attacks showed that Palestinians rejected compromises by Arab authorities with Israel.
kin: Umuyobozi w'ikirenga, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, mu ijambo rye kuri televiziyo yavuze ko imyigaragambyo n'ibitero byo kurwanya Isiraheli byerekanaga ko Abanyapalestine banze kumvikana n'abayobozi b'Abarabu na Isiraheli.
mt0: The supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, in a televised speech said that the protests and attacks against Israel showed that the Palestinians did not agree with Arab and Israeli leaders.

en: Opposition to Israel is a touchstone of belief for Iran, which backs Palestinian and Lebanese Islamist militant groups opposed to peace with Israel, which Tehran does not recognize.
kin: Kurwanya Isiraheli ni ibuye rikomeye ku myizerere ya Irani, ishyigikiye imitwe yitwara gisirikare ya kisilamu ya Palesitine na Libani irwanya amahoro na Isiraheli, Tehran ikaba itemera.
mt0: If you cannot translate it, just say you don't know.

en: "What has happened in Palestine in recent years annuls all plans for compromise with the Zionist enemy (Israel) because no plan for Palestine can be implemented in the absence or contrary to the opinions of its owners, the Palestinians," Khamenei said, speaking in Arabic and addressing Palestinians and other Arabs.
kin: Mu magambo ye, Khamenei yagize ati: "Ibyabereye muri Palesitine mu myaka yashize bivanaho gahunda zose zo kumvikana n’umwanzi w’abaziyoniste (Isiraheli) kuko nta gahunda ya Palesitine ishobora gushyirwa mu bikorwa idahari cyangwa binyuranye n’ibitekerezo bya ba nyirayo, Abanyapalestine". Icyarabu no kuvugana nabanyapalestine nabandi barabu.
mt0: In his words, Khamenei said: "What happened in the past year in the Palestinian territories does not justify any efforts to reach a settlement with the enemy of the Islamic state (Israel) because no Palestinian plan can be implemented without its existence or without its owners, the Palestinians."

en: Thus, Khamenei said, all previous peace agreements -- such as the 1993 Oslo Accords, the two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and former U.S. President Donald Trump's plan dubbed the Deal of the Century "are null and void".
kin: Ni yo mpamvu, Khamenei yavuze ko amasezerano y’amahoro yabanjirije aya - nk’amasezerano ya Oslo yo mu 1993, igisubizo cy’ibihugu byombi kugira ngo gikemure amakimbirane hagati ya Isiraheli na Palesitine, ndetse n’umugambi wahoze ari Perezida wa Leta zunze ubumwe za Amerika, Donald Trump wise amasezerano y’ikinyejana "nta gaciro ufite."
mt0: That's why Khamenei said that previous peace agreements - such as the 1993 Oslo Peace Accords, a solution to the conflict between Israel and Palestine, and Donald Trump's effort to call the millennium agreements "no value."

en: President Ebrahim Raisi, Irans military commanders and senior officials also attended the rallies in which people were allowed to march through the streets, the first time since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic two years ago.
kin: Perezida Ebrahim Raisi, abayobozi b'ingabo za Irans n'abayobozi bakuru na bo bitabiriye imyigaragambyo aho abantu bemerewe kugenda mu mihanda, ku nshuro ya mbere kuva icyorezo cya coronavirus gitangira mu myaka ibiri ishize.

en: Iran's Jerusalem Day rallies are held annually in support of Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state in territories captured by Israel in a 1967 war, on the last Friday of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.
kin: Igiterane cy’umunsi wa Yeruzalemu cya Irani kiba buri mwaka mu rwego rwo gushyigikira Abanyapalestine, bifuza ko Yeruzalemu y’iburasirazuba iba umurwa mukuru w’igihugu kizaza mu turere twafashwe na Isiraheli mu ntambara yo mu 1967, ku wa gatanu wanyuma w’ukwezi kwa Ramazani kwisonzesha kw’abayisilamu.

The Iran Jerusalem Day celebrations are held every year in support of the Palestinians, who want Jerusalem to be the new capital of the country which will be occupied by Israel in the 1967 war, on the last Friday of Ramazan, a Muslim holiday.

en: "Stop your vicious deeds. You know well that we are people of action and reaction," Revolutionary Guards commander Hossein Salami, addressing Israel, told demonstrators in Tehran.
kin: Umuyobozi w'ingabo zishinzwe impinduramatwara, Hossein Salami, yabwiye Isiraheli, yabwiye abigaragambyaga i Tehran ati: "Hagarika ibikorwa byawe bibi. Uzi neza ko turi abantu bakora kandi bakitwara neza."
mt0: The commander of the Islamic Revolutionary Forces, Hossein Salami, told Israel, telling protesters in Tehran, "Stop your evil actions. You know that we are a very responsible and responsible people."

en: "Our responses are painful. You create conditions for your own destruction. We will not leave you alone ...You know better than me what will befall you if you take evil action."
kin: "Ibisubizo byacu birababaje. Ushiraho uburyo bwo kurimbuka kwawe. Ntabwo tuzagutererana wenyine ... Uzi kundusha ibizakubaho uramutse ufashe nabi."
mt0: "Our answers are very sad. You have a way to get over it. We won't let you alone... You know what will happen if you act badly."

en: Iran's military has vowed to retaliate harshly against any attack by Israel, which has often voiced concern over the Iranian nuclear program. Tehran says the program is for peaceful purposes only.

en: Iran, which has one of the biggest missile programs in the Middle East, says its ballistic missiles have a range of up to 2,000 km (1,200 miles) and are capable of reaching its arch-foe Israel and U.S. bases in the region.

en: Over the past year, Iran and the United States have engaged in fitful, indirect talks in Vienna to revive a 2015 nuclear deal that then-President Donald Trump reneged on in 2018 and that Iran, in turn, began violating in 2019.

en: Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in return for relief from economic sanctions.

en: As Fewer Americans Attend Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill the Void?
kin: Nk'uko Abanyamerika bake Bajya mu Itorero, Amaduka ya Kawa Yuzuza Icyuho?
mt0: As many Americans go to church, coffee shops fill the gap?

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society.
kin: Amatorero n'andi mazu asengeramo yagiye akora amateka akomeye mubikorwa bya politiki na politiki muri societe y'Abanyamerika.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
kin: Ariko abantu bake ni bo bitabira ibikorwa by’amadini, kandi kugabanuka kwamatorero nandi mazu yo gusengeramo bikangisha gusiga icyuho gishobora kuzuzwa n'amaduka ya kawa.
mt0: But few people participate in religious activities, and the reduction of churches and temples makes it clear that a gap can be filled by coffee shops.

en: "For so much of American history, the church has really been — or their congregations have really been — essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities … encouraging civic engagement and political participation," says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
kin: Umuyobozi w'ikigo, Daniel Cox agira ati: "Mu mateka menshi y'Abanyamerika, itorero ryabaye - cyangwa amatorero yabo yabaye ngombwa - kugira uruhare rudasanzwe mu gutanga ubumwe no guhuza abaturage… gushishikariza uruhare rw'abaturage no kugira uruhare muri politiki." Ubushakashatsi ku Buzima bw'Abanyamerika na mugenzi wawe mukuru muri American Enterprise Institute.
mt0: The director of the organization, Daniel Cox says: "In many American history, churches - or churches - have been essential to giving communities a sense of unity and unity... to encourage citizens to participate and to participate in politics." The American Enterprise Institute's Consumer Behavior Study and your executive director.

en: "It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church," Cox says.
kin: Cox agira ati: "Ntabwo byari ibintu by'uruhurirane cyangwa amahirwe kuba umuryango uharanira uburenganzira bwa muntu wavuye mu itorero."
mt0: Cox said: "It was not a common or a chance to leave the church.

en: "And you see that cross-culturally … whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important."
kin: "Kandi urabona ko imico itandukanye… haba mu baturage biganjemo abazungu bo mu cyaro, mu nkengero, ahantu hose, amatorero yabaye amateka mu by'ukuri, ni ngombwa."
mt0: And you see that cultures are different... in the rural communities, in the mountains, in the valleys, in all places, churches have become a part of the culture, a necessity."

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
kin: Cox avuga ko amatorero n'andi mazu asengeramo nabyo byagize uruhare mu gufasha abimukira kwimuka bamaze kugera muri Amerika.
mt0: Cox says churches and other religious buildings also helped to help the refugees move to America.

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
kin: Mu 1999, 70% by'Abanyamerika bavuze ko bari mu rusengero, umusigiti cyangwa mu isinagogi.
mt0: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they were in a church, synagogue or synagogue.

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%. A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
kin: Muri 2020, iyo mibare yari yagabanutse kugera kuri 47%. Ubushakashatsi bwakozwe mu mwaka wa 2019 bwerekanye ko Abanyamerika bagera kuri batatu gusa ari bo bavuga ko bitabira amadini ya buri cyumweru.
mt0: In 2020, that number had halved to 47%. A survey in 2019 showed that only three percent of Americans claim to attend Sunday churches.

en: Third places Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" — public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
kin: Umwanya wa gatatu Kutagira uruhare no gufatanya n'amatorero, imisigiti n'amasinagogi bivuze ko abantu bashobora kubura icyo umuhanga mubya societologue wo mumijyi Ray Oldenburg yise "umwanya wa gatatu" - ahantu hateranira abantu benshi batanga ikintu murugo, "umwanya wa mbere," nakazi, "umwanya wa kabiri," ntabwo.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know the Third Time.

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
kin: Oldenburg yavuze ko umwanya wa gatatu ari ingenzi ku mibereho y'abaturage.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
kin: Ubushakashatsi bwakozwe mu Kwakira 2021 bwakozwe n’ikigo cy’Abanyamerika gishinzwe ubushakashatsi bwerekanye ko ahantu h’ubucuruzi nk’amazu ya kawa bitera kwizerana no guhuza imiryango y'Abanyamerika kandi bikaba byafasha kuziba icyuho cyasizwe n'amatorero.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. A study published in October 2021 by the American Institute for Research shows that coffee shops promote friendship and unity among American families and help to fill the gap left by churches.

en: "If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good," says clinical psychologist Dr. Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
kin: Inzobere mu by'imitekerereze ya muntu, Dr. Maria Espinola, umwarimu wungirije mu ishami ry’indwara zo mu mutwe, agira ati: "Niba usanzwe muri cafe, barista irashobora kumenya icyo usanzwe utumiza, kandi barashobora kukugukorera, kandi ibyo ni byiza." na Neuroscience Imyitwarire muri kaminuza ya Cincinnati College of Medicine.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know a psychiatrist, Dr. Maria Espinola, a associate professor of psychiatry at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine, says: "If you're a regular in a cafe, the barista can know what you're ordering, and they can do it for you, and that's fine."

en: "It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways," Espinola says.
kin: "Ni byiza kumenyekana, kumenya ko abantu bagutegereje, kumenya ko abantu bakwitayeho, kumenya ko uri uwawe, kuko gukenera kuba hamwe no guhuza abantu nikintu cyibanze twese dufite, kandi ni ngombwa kugira ngo ibyo bisohozwe mu buryo butandukanye, "Espinola.
mt0: "It's good to be recognized, to know that people are waiting for you, to know that people care about you, to know that you are your own, because being together and being connected is something we all have, and it's important to express that in different ways," says Espinola.

en: "So, places like third places can allow us to do that."
kin: "Rero, ahantu nka gatatu harashobora kutwemerera kubikora."
mt0: So, there is a place like that that can allow us to do that.

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
kin: Mu bihe byashize, amatorero n'andi mazu yo gusengeramo yabaye umwanya wa gatatu ku Banyamerika benshi.
mt0: In the past, churches and other religious places were the third most popular place in the United States.

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place — a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other place in their community that they visit regularly.
kin: Muri 2019, 67% by'abantu babajijwe bavuze ko bafite umwanya wa gatatu - iduka rya kawa, akabari, resitora, parike cyangwa ahandi hantu basura buri gihe.
mt0: In 2019, 67% of the people surveyed said they had a third place - a coffee shop, restaurant, park or other place they visited every day.

en: That number dropped to 56% in 2021 — a number that could have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

mt0: If you cannot translate, just say you don't know. The number fell to 56% in 2021 - the number that could have been infected with COVID-19.

en: "What we found was that people who had a third place were much more connected to their community," says Cox. "They're much more likely to engage in other activities there.
kin: Cox agira ati: "Icyo twabonye ni uko abantu bafite umwanya wa gatatu bari bahuze cyane n'abaturage babo". "Birashoboka cyane ko bakora ibikorwa bindi.
mt0: "What we saw was that the people who were in the third place were very close to their people." "It is very likely that they would do other things."

en: They are much more trusting of their neighbors. There's a whole great array of positive social outcomes that were connected to having a third place … and for a lot of Americans, it's a coffee shop or a cafe."
kin: Barizera cyane abaturanyi babo. Hano hari byinshi byiza byagezweho mu mibereho bifitanye isano no kugira umwanya wa gatatu… kandi ku Banyamerika benshi, ni ikawa cyangwa ikawa. "

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country, and anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.
kin: Icyo amaduka yikawa abifitemo inyungu nuko ashobora kuboneka hafi ya hose, mugihugu cyose, kandi umuntu wese ubishaka ashobora guhagarara buri gihe.

kin: Kandi benshi barakinguye iminsi myinshi yicyumweru.

en: What US Mayors Are Most Worried About After the Pandemic
kin: Ibyo abayobozi ba Amerika bahangayikishijwe cyane na byo nyuma y'icyorezo
mt0: That's what the American leaders are most concerned about after the outbreak of the virus. If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Americas mayors are most concerned about the lingering mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a nationwide survey of 126 mayors conducted during the summer of 2021.
kin: Abayobozi ba Amerika bahangayikishijwe cyane n’ingaruka ziterwa n’ubuzima bwo mu mutwe bw’icyorezo cya COVID-19, nk’uko ubushakashatsi bwakozwe mu gihugu hose bwakorewe ku bayobozi 126 bwakozwe mu mpeshyi ya 2021.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: The respondents headed cities with at least 75,000 residents. The local leaders are still focused on traditional issues such as violent crime, the economy and infrastructure, but they are most concerned about the pandemics long-term impact on the mental health of their constituents.
kin: Ababajijwe bayoboye imijyi byibuze abaturage 75.000. Abayobozi b'inzego z'ibanze baracyibanda ku bibazo gakondo nk'ibyaha by'urugomo, ubukungu n'ibikorwa remezo, ariko bahangayikishijwe cyane n'ingaruka z'icyorezo ku buzima bwo mu mutwe bw'abatoye.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Mental health was top of mind for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in November 2021.
kin: Ubuzima bwo mu mutwe bwibanze kuri Michael Udine ubwo yarahiraga kuba umuyobozi w’intara ya Broward, muri Floride, mu Gushyingo 2021.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: "Everything that was a potential issue pre-pandemic has pretty much been exacerbated by the pandemic," he says.
kin: Agira ati: "Ikintu cyose cyashoboraga kuba ikibazo mbere y’icyorezo cyarushijeho kwiyongera kubera icyorezo."
mt0: "Everything that could have been a problem before the virus grew worse because of the virus."

en: "There were issues going into the pandemic, and it was becoming more and more important on everyone's radar screen about the mental health of people of all ages. And I think the pandemic pretty much supercharged those issues."
kin: "Hariho ibibazo byagiye mu cyorezo, kandi byagendaga birushaho kuba ingenzi kuri ecran ya radar ya buri muntu ku bijyanye n'ubuzima bwo mu mutwe bw'abantu b'ingeri zose. Kandi ndatekereza ko icyorezo cyarenze ibyo bibazo."
mt0: There were problems which went into the virus, and they were increasingly being a foreign tourist on the ecran of every person's radar screen for the health of all people. And I think the virus was beyond those problems.

en: It is not unusual for large outbreaks of disease to have a negative impact on mental health, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reports that rates of anxiety and depressive disorders among adults increased during the pandemic.
kin: Ntibisanzwe ko icyorezo kinini cy’indwara kigira ingaruka mbi ku buzima bwo mu mutwe, nk’uko ikigo gishinzwe kurwanya no gukumira indwara kibitangaza, ngo raporo y’uko abantu bahangayitse ndetse n’indwara yo kwiheba yiyongera mu gihe cy’icyorezo.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know It is not unusual for a large epidemic to have negative effects on mental health, as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports, reports of anxiety and depression are increasing during the epidemic.

en: The pandemic has also adversely influenced the emotional and mental health of about one-third of Americas youth.
kin: Icyorezo kandi cyagize ingaruka mbi ku buzima bw'amarangamutima no mu mutwe by'urubyiruko rwo muri Amerika.
mt0: The experiment also had a negative impact on the mental and emotional health of young Americans.

en: "What we've seen is just such anxiety, kids who wouldn't ordinarily have a meltdown, because it's so much change and difficulty adjusting to transitions," Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord told VOA last month. "We've also seen a lot more sadness and depression."
kin: Mu kwezi gushize, umuhanga mu by'imitekerereze ya muntu witwa Maryland, Mary Karapetian, Alvord, yabwiye ibiro ntaramakuru by'Abanyamerika ati: "Ibyo twabonye ni impungenge nk'izo, abana badakunze kugira ikibazo cyo gushonga, kubera ko ari impinduka nyinshi kandi bigoye guhindura inzibacyuho." "Twabonye kandi umubabaro mwinshi no kwiheba."
mt0: In the month of October, a psychologist from Maryland, Mary Karapetian, Alvord, told the United States Press Office that "we found such concerns, children who are not often affected by losing weight, because it is a lot of changes and it is difficult to change the patterns." "We also found a lot of sadness and anxiety."

en: Early on in the pandemic, mayors were more focused on city operations, budget shortfalls and the threat the pandemic posed to small businesses, according to David Glick, an associate professor of political science at Boston University and a co-author of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.
kin: Nk’uko byatangajwe na David Glick, umwarimu wungirije wa siyanse ya politiki muri kaminuza ya Boston, akaba n'umwanditsi umwe w’ubushakashatsi bwakozwe na Menino 2021, nk'uko byatangajwe na David Glick, umwarimu wungirije ushinzwe ubushakashatsi mu bya politiki, nk'uko byatangajwe na David Glick.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. David Glick, a professor of politics at the University of Boston, is one of the authors of the Menino 2021 study, according to David Glick, a professor of politics.

en: "Some of those concerns still remain, but what we saw more of in 2021 … is concern about some of the long-term impacts on individual residents," Glick says.
kin: Glick agira ati: "Zimwe muri izo mpungenge ziracyahari, ariko ibyo twabonye byinshi mu 2021… ni impungenge z'ingaruka z'igihe kirekire ku baturage ku giti cyabo."
mt0: Glick said: "Some of these concerns are still alive, but what we saw in 2021... is concern about long-term effects on individuals."

en: "Concerns about polarization over vaccines and just people being pushed to their limits … and certainly less on their city budgets and revenues and having to cut programs and some of those types of things that were probably more top of mind earlier in the pandemic."
kin: "Guhangayikishwa no gukingira inkingo ndetse n'abantu basunikwa ku mipaka yabo… kandi rwose ni bike ku ngengo y’imari y’umujyi n’amafaranga yinjira ndetse no kugabanya gahunda ndetse na bimwe muri ibyo bintu byashobokaga kuba byaragaragaye mbere mu cyorezo."
mt0: "The concerns about vaccinations and border control... and really, it's very little on the city budget and income tax and the reduction of some of the programs and some of the things that could have been already visible before the pandemic."

en: Over half of mayors, 52%, are worried about "lingering mental health challenges and trauma," according to the survey.
kin: Ubushakashatsi buvuga ko kimwe cya kabiri cy’abayobozi, 52%, bahangayikishijwe n’ikibazo cy’ubuzima bwo mu mutwe n’ihungabana.

en: Additionally, more than one-third of mayors, 37%, are worried about learning loss among young people.
kin: Byongeye kandi, kimwe cya gatatu cyabayobozi, 37%, bahangayikishijwe no gutakaza imyigire mu rubyiruko.
mt0: Also, one-third of managers, 37%, are concerned about the lack of education among young people.

en: "Second only to mental health and trauma, and they're probably not totally independent concerns," Glick says.

en: "It is part of that shift of mayors concerns from immediate threats to businesses closing and people getting sick, to some of these longer-term consequences that are going to persist in the future.
kin: "Ni bimwe mu byo guhindura abayobozi b'abayobozi biturutse ku iterabwoba ryihuse ku bucuruzi no gufunga abantu, kuri zimwe mu ngaruka z'igihe kirekire zizakomeza kubaho mu gihe kiri imbere.

en: And learning loss among their students, theyre worried it's going to persist for many, many, many years into the future. It's hard to make up for."

en: According to the survey, other top concerns for Americas mayors include the financial insecurity of low-income residents (33%), the closing of small businesses (29%) and increased crime and violence (26%).
kin: Nk’uko ubushakashatsi bwabigaragaje, izindi mpungenge z’abayobozi b’Amerika zirimo umutekano muke w’amafaranga ku baturage bafite amikoro make (33%), guhagarika imishinga mito (29%) no kongera ibyaha n’ihohoterwa (26%).

en: Just 7% of mayors are worried about the shift to remote work and the long-term impact that could have on outmigration — people moving away from their cities.
kin: 7% by'abayobozi gusa bafite impungenge zo kwimukira mu kazi ka kure n'ingaruka z'igihe kirekire zishobora kugira ku kwimuka - abantu bava mu migi yabo.

en: "What we're seeing is a large majority are using it for things they consider to be transformative and will make major changes to their cities," Glick says, "instead of feeling obligated or feeling the necessity to use it to plug up over-budget gaps to keep the doors open and the lights on."

en: "They've lived in a home for so long and they want to be able to reduce their expenses on a fixed income," he says.
kin: Agira ati: "Babaye mu rugo igihe kirekire kandi barashaka kugabanya amafaranga bakoresheje ku musaruro uteganijwe."

en: "They want to live in a social cohort, like a retirement community, and things like that where it's much more socially amenable to them."
kin: "Bashaka gutura mu mibereho, nk'umuryango w'izabukuru, n'ibindi nk'ibyo aho biborohera cyane kuri bo."
mt0: "They want to live in a stable, stable environment, such as a family of happiness, and so on.

en: The asking price of apartment rentals was up 10.7% in September 2021 compared to last year at the same time, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
kin: Nk’uko Ishyirahamwe ry’Abacuruzi (NAR) ribitangaza ngo muri Nzeri 2021, igiciro cy’ubukode bw’amazu cyazamutseho 10.7% muri Nzeri 2021 ugereranije n’umwaka ushize.
mt0: If you cannot translate, just say you don't know.

en: "It's a hot market. We have never seen this market so hot in the last decade," says Gay Cororaton, NARs senior economist and director of housing and commercial research. "The average rent growth, year-over-year, is about 3-to-5%. We're seeing 11% rent growth now, so, clearly, way above trends weve had in the past."
kin: Gay Cororaton, impuguke mu by'ubukungu akaba n'umuyobozi ushinzwe imiturire n'ubushakashatsi mu bucuruzi, agira ati: "Ni isoko rishyushye. Ntabwo twigeze tubona iri soko rishyushye cyane mu myaka icumi ishize."
mt0: "It's a hot market. We've never seen such a hot market in the past ten years." Gay Cororaton, a economist and chief executive of the housing and business research department, said: "It's a hot market. We've never seen such a hot market in the past ten years."

en: Renters are feeling the squeeze because the COVID-19 pandemic caused supply chain issues, slowing down home building in the United States.

en: The housing supply got even tighter during the pandemic as more investors put their money into housing, according to Cororaton, while existing homeowners looked for second homes.

What? That means that it is a very successful and very competitive market that will continue to grow."

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
kin: Bamwe mu bahanga mu by'ubuvuzi bagaragaje impungenge z'uko ingamba zo gukumira COVID-19, nko guhisha no kwishuri rya kure, zishobora kugabanya intege nke z'abana babakingira indwara zisanzwe zo mu bwana.
mt0: Some doctors have expressed concerns that restrictions on COVID-19, such as quarantine and distance learning, could reduce the ability of children to protect themselves from common childhood diseases.

en: "There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things," says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
kin: Hariho impamvu nyinshi zituma twemera ko abana bakeneye guhura nibintu kugirango bagumane ubudahangarwa bwabo, kuburyo nibaramuka bahuye nikintu kibi cyane, bafite ingingo zubudahangarwa bwabo zishobora kwambuka zikabafasha kubarinda ibyo bintu, ibi bikaba byavuzwe na Sara Sawyer, umwarimu w’ibinyabuzima bya molekuline, selile n’iterambere muri kaminuza ya Colorado Boulder.
mt0: There are many reasons why we believe that children need to be exposed to things to lose their immunity, so if they get very exposed to something bad, their immune system can pass and protect them, Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular biology, cell and evolution at the University of Colorado Boulder said.

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
kin: Mu gihe cyo kuvuka, impinja zitagira kivurira zibona antibodi kuri ba nyina amashereka, abafasha kubarinda kugeza igihe bazubaka ubudahangarwa bwabo.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know. When babies are born, they get antibodies from their mothers' breasts, which help them protect themselves until they develop their immune system.

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.
kin: Ntabwo ari impanuka ko abana batangira gushyira ibintu mu munwa bakimara kugira ubuhanga buhagije bwo gutoragura ibintu.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: "They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity. That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
kin: Sawyer agira ati: "Ibyo babikora kubera ko batoranya ibidukikije kandi bakubaka ubudahangarwa bwabo. Iyo ni imwe mu bwihindurize."
mt0: Sawyer said: "They do this because they choose their environment and build their defenses. That's one of the changes."

en: "They're exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
kin: Bagaragaza umubiri wabo kuri mikorobe mu buryo runaka, bwo kubaka ubudahangarwa bwabo. Abantu bamwe rero bavuga ko indwara zo mu bwana, nk'ubukonje ndetse n'udukoko two mu gifu, byubaka ubudahangarwa bwacu kugira ngo igihe ibintu byinshi biteye akaga, twiteguye kandi ntituzarwara muri ibyo bintu bibi cyane.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Even before the pandemic, epidemiological evidence suggested that children in more developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizer are more prevalent, might have less-developed immune systems compared to kids in developing nations who are routinely exposed to more bacteria, viruses and allergens.
kin: Ndetse na mbere y’icyorezo, ibimenyetso by’ibyorezo byerekanaga ko abana bo mu bihugu byateye imbere cyane, aho gukaraba intoki no gukoresha isuku byiganje, bashobora kuba bafite sisitemu y’umubiri idateye imbere ugereranije n’abana bo mu bihugu bikiri mu nzira y'amajyambere bakunze guhura na bagiteri nyinshi, virusi na allergene. .
mt0: Even before the epidemic, symptoms of the epidemic showed that children in developed countries, where hand washing and hygiene are a priority, may have a weaker immune system compared to children in developing countries who are more likely to be exposed to many bacteria, viruses and allergens.

en: This makes kids in more industrialized countries more vulnerable to developing autoimmune diseases, according to whats known as the "hygiene hypothesis."
kin: Ibi bituma abana bo mu bihugu byinshi byateye imbere bibasirwa n'indwara ziterwa na autoimmune, ukurikije icyo bita "hypothesis yisuku."
mt0: This causes many children in developed countries to be affected by autoimmune diseases, according to what they call the "hypothesis of infection."

en: "The hygiene hypothesis is actually quite controversial because it's thought that our exposure to microbes isn't the only factor," says Cody Warren, a virologist and immunologist who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder.
kin: Cody Warren, inzobere mu bijyanye na virusi akaba n'umu immunologue akaba ari umunyeshuri w’iposita muri kaminuza ya Colorado Boulder, agira ati: "Igitekerezo cy’isuku mu byukuri ntikivugwaho rumwe kuko twibwira ko guhura na mikorobe atari byo byonyine."
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know Cody Warren, a virus expert and immunologist, and a postgraduate student at the University of Colorado Boulder, says: "The theory of infection is not fully accepted because we believe that bacteria are not the only thing that causes infection."

en: "A lot of this could also be dictated by genetics, diet, and the environment that we live in.
kin: Byinshi muri byo bishobora nanone guterwa na genetiki, imirire, n'ibidukikije dutuyemo. Ibyo kandi bigira uruhare runini mumubiri… nikintu gifatika tudashobora kubara byuzuye twambaye masike. Hariho ibindi bintu bijya muri iryo gereranya.
mt0: Many of these can also be linked to genetics, diet, and environment. These also play a big role in the body... it's something we can't fully measure without a measuring tape. There are other things that go into this comparison.

en: Warren, the father of three young children, says spending lots of time outdoors is one way to balance the negatives of isolation.
kin: Warren, se w'abana batatu bato, avuga ko kumara umwanya munini hanze ari bumwe mu buryo bwo guhuza ibibi byo kwigunga.
mt0: Warren, father of three young children, says spending a lot of time outdoors is one way to combine the bad effects of being isolated.

en: "Just exploring microbes in the environment also is benefiting [and] training our immune system," Warren says. "Our immune systems get trained through the foods that we eat, which also have microorganisms on them.
kin: Warren agira ati: "Gusa gukora ubushakashatsi kuri mikorobe mu bidukikije nabyo byunguka [no] guhugura umubiri." "Ubudahangarwa bw'umubiri bwacu butozwa binyuze mu biryo turya, bifite na mikorobe kuri byo.
mt0: Warren said: "However, looking at bacteria in the environment also benefits [no] healing the body." "Our immune system is built up through food we eat, which has bacteria on it."

en: And so, despite the fact that we've kind of been hunkered down a little bit, I do feel that our immune systems will catch up."
kin: Kandi rero, nubwo twaba twarahigishijwe gato, ndumva ko ubudahangarwa bwacu buzafatwa. "
mt0: So, even if we've been briefed a little, I think our resistance will be taken.

en: There are other things parents can do, he says, to boost their childrens immune systems during pandemic times.
kin: Avuga ko hari ibindi bintu ababyeyi bashobora gukora, kugirango bongere abana babo ubudahangarwa bw'umubiri mugihe cyibyorezo.
mt0: He says that there are other things parents can do to increase their children's immune system during the illness.

en: "One of the most important things you can do is just to stay up to date on vaccines.
kin: "Kimwe mu bintu by'ingenzi ushobora gukora ni ugukomeza kugezwaho amakuru ku nkingo.
mt0: One of the most important things you can do is to continue to get information about the vaccine.

en: That's one of the best ways that we have to train our immune systems," Warren says.
kin: Ubu ni bumwe mu buryo bwiza tugomba kumenyereza umubiri, "Warren.
mt0: This is one of the best ways we should get used to our body," said Warren.

en: "But also, equally important is making sure our children have a good diet and they regulate stress.
kin: Ariko nanone, icy'ingenzi ni ukureba niba abana bacu bafite indyo yuzuye kandi bagenga imihangayiko. Byanditswe neza ko ibyo byombi - kugira indyo yuzuye, ibidukikije bidahangayikishije - bishobora kugira ingaruka nziza ku mikorere yacu.
mt0: But, the most important is to see if our children are healthy and able to cope with stress. It is well written that both - having a healthy diet and a stress-free environment - can have positive effects on our ability to function.

en: Once public health officials say masks are no longer necessary, Sawyer thinks pointing out the positives of putting our masks away could reassure hesitant parents who worry about their children getting sick.
kin: Abashinzwe ubuzima rusange bamaze kuvuga ko masike atagikenewe, Sawyer atekereza ko kwerekana ibyiza byo gushyira maska ​​yacu bishobora guhumuriza ababyeyi bashidikanya bahangayikishijwe n’abana babo barwara.
mt0: Since the health authorities have said that masks are no longer needed, Sawyer thinks that showing the benefits of wearing our masks could help calm those worried about their children being ill.

en: "Maybe we should have a public conversation about the possible reasons to take that mask off, if they are in school, and get back to the normal repertoire of relatively safe childhood illnesses," she says.
kin: Agira ati: "Ahari twakagombye kugirana ikiganiro mbwirwaruhame ku mpamvu zishoboka zo gukuramo iyo mask, niba bari ku ishuri, hanyuma tugasubira mu ndirimbo zisanzwe z’indwara zo mu bwana zifite umutekano."
mt0: "We should have a public debate on the possibility of taking off the mask, if they are at school, and then sing the normal children's songs of safety."

en: "The plus side of childhood illnesses is that they can build up that hornet's nest of immunity that could protect kids against new things that then come along."
kin: Icyiza cy’indwara zo mu bwana ni uko zishobora kubaka icyari cya hornet cy’ubudahangarwa gishobora kurinda abana ibintu bishya hanyuma bikaza.
mt0: The good thing about child diseases is that they can build a hormone defense system that can protect children from new things and then return.

en: US Quietly Expands Asylum Limits While Preparing to End Them
kin: Amerika Yaguye Bituje Imipaka Yubuhunzi Mugihe Yitegura Kubarangiza
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: The Biden administration has begun expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans to Mexico under pandemic-related powers to deny migrants a chance to seek asylum, expanding use of the rule even as it publicly says it has been trying to unwind it, officials said Wednesday.
kin: Ku wa gatatu, abayobozi bavuze ko ubuyobozi bwa Biden bwatangiye kwirukana Abanyakanani na Nikaragwa muri Mexico kubera ububasha bujyanye n’icyorezo bwo kwima abimukira amahirwe yo gusaba ubuhungiro, kwagura ikoreshwa ry’iryo tegeko nubwo rivuga ku mugaragaro ko ryagerageje kubireka.
mt0: Officials said on Wednesday that the administration of Biden began to remove citizens from Nicaragua and Nicaragua because of the authority to deny asylum, extending the use of the law even though it says it has tried to stop it.

en: The U.S. struck agreement with Mexico to expel up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans a day from three locations: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; and Rio Grande Valley, Texas, according to a U.S. official with direct knowledge of the effort.
kin: Amerika yagiranye amasezerano na Mexico yo kwirukana abanya Cuba 100 na Nikaragwa 20 kumunsi ahantu hatatu: San Diego; El Paso, muri Texas; n'ikibaya cya Rio Grande, muri Texas, nk'uko byatangajwe n'umuyobozi wa Amerika ufite ubumenyi butaziguye bw'imbaraga.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: The expulsions began April 27 and will end May 22, the official told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the agreement has not been made public.
kin: Iyirukanwa ryatangiye ku ya 27 Mata rikazarangira ku ya 22 Gicurasi, nk'uko uyu muyobozi yabitangarije ibiro ntaramakuru by'Abanyamerika kugira ngo atamenyekana kubera ko ayo masezerano atashyizwe ahagaragara.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: They are carried out under Title 42 authority, a public health law that has been used to expel migrants on grounds of preventing spread of COVID-19. Title 42 is due to expire May 23, unless a judge intervenes.
kin: Bikorerwa munsi yumutwe wa 42, itegeko ryubuzima rusange ryakoreshejwe mu kwirukana abimukira ku mpamvu zo gukumira ikwirakwizwa rya COVID-19. Umutwe wa 42 ugomba kurangira ku ya 23 Gicurasi, keretse umucamanza abigizemo uruhare.
mt0: It is under Article 42, which is the basic health law used to quarantine migrants for the purpose of preventing the spread of COVID-19. Article 42 must end on May 23, unless a court has acted in favour of it.

en: The U.S. and Mexico agreed April 26 to a very limited number of expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans, according to a high-level Mexican official who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly.
kin: Nk’uko byatangajwe n'umuyobozi wo mu rwego rwo hejuru wo muri Megizike wavuze ko atigeze atangazwa kubera ko batemerewe kugira icyo batangaza ku mugaragaro, Amerika na Mexico byumvikanye ku ya 26 Mata ku mubare muto cyane wo kwirukana Abanyakanani na Nikaragwa.
mt0: According to a top official of Mexico who said he did not know because he was not allowed to speak publicly, the United States and Mexico agreed on a very small number of border borders.

en: It was prompted by higher numbers of migrants from those two countries coming to the U.S. border.
kin: Byatewe numubare munini w’abimukira bava muri ibyo bihugu byombi baza kumupaka wa Amerika.
mt0: It was due to a large number of immigrants from both countries coming to the US border.

en: Mexico also took into account that the U.S. government had started processing visas in Cuba again, the official said. Mexico had also begun processing visas for Cubans.
kin: Uyu muyobozi yavuze ko Mexico kandi yazirikanye ko guverinoma y'Amerika yatangiye gutunganya viza muri Cuba. Mexico nayo yari yatangiye gutunganya viza kubanya Cuba.
mt0: The official also said that Mexico would not be able to recognize that the United States started issuing visa to Cuba. Mexico already started issuing visa to Cuba.

en: Another Mexican official, also not authorized to comment publicly, confirmed that up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans were being expelled from San Diego under Title 42.
kin: Undi muyobozi wo muri Megizike, na we utemerewe kugira icyo atangaza ku mugaragaro, yemeje ko Abanyakanani bagera kuri 100 na Nikaragwa 20 birukanwa muri San Diego ku mutwe wa 42.
mt0: A third official, who is not allowed to speak publicly, confirmed that 100 Canadians and 20 Nikaragwa were deported from San Diego on the 42nd Street.

en: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
kin: Minisiteri ishinzwe umutekano mu gihugu cya Amerika ntabwo yahise isubiza icyifuzo cyo gutanga ibisobanuro.
mt0: The United States Ministry of Defense did not respond to the request for clarification.

en: Until last week, Mexico only agreed to take Guatemalans, Hondurans and El Salvadorans — in addition to Mexicans — under Title 42 authority. Other nationalities are subject to Title 42 but costs, strained diplomatic ties and other considerations often make it difficult to send them back to their home countries.
kin: Kugeza mu cyumweru gishize, Mexico yemeye gufata Guatemala, Hondurans na El Salvadorans - usibye Abanyamegizike - ku butegetsi bwa 42. Abandi benegihugu bagengwa na Umutwe wa 42 ariko ikiguzi, umubano wububanyi n’ububanyi n’ibindi bitekerezo akenshi biragoye kubasubiza mu bihugu byabo.
mt0: Since last week, Mexico has agreed to take Guatemala, Hondurans and El Salvadorans - except the Mexicans - under the 42nd Executive. Other citizens are subject to the 42nd Executive but the cost, friendship and friendship often make it difficult to return them to their countries.

en: It's next to impossible for the U.S. to expel migrants to Cuba or Nicaragua because of poor relations with those governments.
kin: Bikurikira ntibishoboka ko Amerika yirukana abimukira muri Cuba cyangwa Nikaragwa kubera umubano mubi na guverinoma.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: That has posed a challenge for the Biden administration as more people from those countries seek haven in the United States.
kin: Ibyo byateje ikibazo ubuyobozi bwa Biden mugihe abantu benshi baturuka muri ibyo bihugu bashaka ubuhungiro muri Amerika.
mt0: This has caused problems to Biden's administration because many people from these countries are seeking asylum in the United States.

en: Cubans were stopped by U.S. authorities more than 32,000 times on the Mexican border in March, double the number in February and more than five times October's count, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Nicaragua eased travel restrictions from Cuba in November, making it easier for Cubans to continue by land to the U.S. border. Most enter the U.S. in or near Yuma, Arizona, and Del Rio, Texas.
kin: Nk’uko byatangajwe na gasutamo ya Leta zunze ubumwe za Amerika, ngo abanya Cuba bahagaritswe n'abayobozi b'Abanyamerika inshuro zirenga 32.000 ku mupaka wa Mexico, bakubye kabiri muri Gashyantare ndetse bakubye inshuro zirenga eshanu Ukwakira. Nikaragwa yorohereje imbogamizi z’ingendo ziva muri Cuba mu Gushyingo, byorohereza Abanyakanada gukomeza ku butaka kugera ku mupaka wa Amerika. Benshi binjira muri Amerika cyangwa hafi ya Yuma, Arizona, na Del Rio, Texas.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know

en: Nicaraguans were stopped more than 16,000 times in March, more than double September's level. The vast majority enter in South Texas.
kin: Muri Werurwe, Nikaragwa yahagaritswe inshuro zirenga 16.000, irenga inshuro ebyiri Nzeri. Umubare munini winjira muri Texas yepfo.
mt0: In March, Nikaragwa was blocked more than 16.000 times, more than twice in September. The majority of them entered the southern Texas.

en: Lifting Title 42 has proved controversial as midterm elections near, even for Biden's Democratic Party, amid concerns that the U.S. is unprepared for an anticipated increase in migrants seeking asylum. Authorities stopped migrants more than 221,000 times in March, the highest mark in 22 years.
kin: Kuzamura Umutwe wa 42 byagaragaye ko bitavugwaho rumwe nk’amatora yo hagati, ndetse no mu ishyaka rya demokarasi rya Biden, mu gihe hari impungenge z’uko Amerika ititeguye kwiyongera kw’abimukira bashaka ubuhungiro. Muri Werurwe, abategetsi bahagaritse abimukira inshuro zirenga 221.000, kikaba aricyo kintu kinini mu myaka 22.

en: The White House and Homeland Security Department have publicly stood behind the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's decision to end the measure because it could no longer be justified on grounds of protecting public health.
kin: Ishami ry’umutekano n’umutekano mu gihugu ryashyigikiye ku mugaragaro icyemezo cy’ikigo gishinzwe kurwanya no gukumira indwara cyo guhagarika iki cyemezo kuko kitagishoboye kuba gifite ishingiro kubera kurengera ubuzima rusange.
mt0: The National Security and Defense Committee supported the decision of the CDC to suspend this measure because it could not be justified because of the safety of the public.

en: But the practice of expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans runs counter to the administration's public statements that it was phasing out use of the pandemic powers to prepare for May 23.
kin: Ariko imyitozo yo kwirukana abanya Cuba na Nikaragwa irahabanye n’ubuyobozi bwatangaje ko bwagiye bukuraho imbaraga z’icyorezo kugira ngo bitegure ku ya 23 Gicurasi.
mt0: But the exercises for the removal of Cubans and Nikaragwa have been interrupted by the government which announced that it had reduced its capacity to prepare for May 23.

en: The U.S. has expelled migrants more than 1.8 million times under Title 42 authority since March 2020, effectively overriding rights to seek asylum under U.S. law and international treaty. In doing so, migrants are not subject to immigration law, which include rights to seek protection from persecution at home.
kin: Kuva muri Werurwe 2020, Amerika yirukanye abimukira inshuro zirenga miliyoni 1.8 ku butegetsi bwa Umutwe wa 42, bivuguruza uburenganzira bwo gusaba ubuhungiro hakurikijwe amategeko ya Amerika n'amasezerano mpuzamahanga. Mu kubikora, abimukira ntibagengwa n'amategeko y’abinjira, akubiyemo uburenganzira bwo kurindwa ibitotezo mu ngo.
mt0: Since March 2020, the United States has deported more than 1.8 million immigrants under the 42nd President, changing the right to seek asylum under the United States and international agreements. In doing so, immigrants are not subject to the immigration laws, including the right to be protected from abuse in their homes.

en: The administration said in court filings that it began processing more Central American adults under immigration laws after the CDC's announcement on April 1. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that it couldn't start unwinding Title 42 while it was still in effect.
kin: Ubuyobozi bwatangaje mu rukiko ko bwatangiye gutunganya abantu benshi bakuze bo muri Amerika yo Hagati bakurikiza amategeko y’abinjira nyuma y’uko CDC ibitangaza ku ya 1 Mata.
mt0: The government announced in court that it began to quarantine many older adults in Central America who had been following the CDC's announcement on April 1.

en: U.S. District Judge Robert Summerhays strongly criticized the CDC's decision, suggesting he would try to keep Title 42 in effect after May 23. A hearing is scheduled May 13 for oral arguments.
kin: Umucamanza w'akarere ka Amerika, Robert Summerhays, yanenze cyane icyemezo cya CDC, avuga ko azagerageza gukomeza Umutwe wa 42 nyuma y'itariki ya 23 Gicurasi.
mt0: The US District Attorney Robert Summerhays, harshly criticized the decision by the CDC, saying he would try to extend the 42nd Session after May 23.

en: Marisa Limon, senior director of advocacy and planning at the Hope Border Institute, said advocates began learning about expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans from El Paso on Monday and later confirmed the new practice with U.S. officials.
kin: Umuyobozi mukuru ushinzwe ubuvugizi n’igenamigambi mu kigo cya Hope Border, Marisa Limon, yavuze ko abunganizi batangiye kwiga ibijyanye no kwirukana Abanyakanani na Nikaragwa muri El Paso ku wa mbere nyuma baza kwemeza imikorere mishya hamwe n’abayobozi ba Amerika.
mt0: The head of advocacy and planning at Hope Border, Marisa Limon, said experts began to study the removal of the Native Americans and Nikaragwa from El Paso on Monday and approved the new procedures with American officials.

en: Limon said the administration is "trying to get every last bit out of Title 42" before it expires.
kin: Limon yavuze ko ubuyobozi "bugerageza gukuramo buri kintu cya nyuma mu mutwe wa 42" kitararangira.

en: She called it "sobering" but consistent with the administration's efforts to have other countries in the Western hemisphere take more responsibility for hosting people fleeing their homes.
